The **2018 Maine gubernatorial election** will take place on November 6, 2018,
to elect the next [governor of Maine](/wiki/Governor_of_Maine "Governor of
Maine"). It will occur along with elections for the [U.S.
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Maine,_2018 "United States
Senate election in Maine, 2018"), [U.S.
House](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections_in_Maine,_2018
"United States House of Representatives elections in Maine, 2018"), and other
state and local elections. Incumbent
[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)") Governor [Paul LePage](/wiki/Paul_LePage "Paul LePage") is
term limited and cannot seek reelection to a third consecutive term in office.

The primaries for this election were the first in Maine to be conducted with
[ranked choice voting](/wiki/Ranked_choice_voting "Ranked choice voting")
(RCV), as opposed to a simple plurality, after voters passed [a citizen
referendum](/wiki/Maine_Question_5,_2016 "Maine Question 5, 2016") approving
the change in 2016.[1] An [advisory opinion](/wiki/Advisory_opinion "Advisory
opinion") by the [Maine Supreme Judicial
Court](/wiki/Maine_Supreme_Judicial_Court "Maine Supreme Judicial Court") held
that RCV would be unconstitutional for general elections for governor and the
state legislature. This led state legislators to vote to delay its
implementation pending approval of a state constitutional amendment.[2][3]
Backers of a "people's veto" turned in enough signatures to suspend this law
until a [June referendum vote](/wiki/Maine_Question_1,_June_2018 "Maine
Question 1, June 2018"), which restored RCV for future primary and
congressional elections.[4]

Governor [Paul LePage](/wiki/Paul_LePage "Paul LePage") threatened not to
certify the results of the primary elections, saying he would "leave it up to
the courts to decide."[5] He also called the use of ranked-choice voting the
"most horrific thing in the world."[6] Secretary of State [Matthew
Dunlap](/wiki/Matthew_Dunlap "Matthew Dunlap") said the results would be
binding regardless of whether LePage certified them.[7]

The Republican nominee is businessman and [2010 independent
candidate](/wiki/Maine_gubernatorial_election,_2010 "Maine gubernatorial
election, 2010") for governor Shawn Moody. The Democratic candidate is
[Attorney General](/wiki/Maine_Attorney_General "Maine Attorney General")
[Janet Mills](/wiki/Janet_T._Mills "Janet T. Mills"). [State
Treasurer](/wiki/Maine_State_Treasurer "Maine State Treasurer") [Terry
Hayes](/wiki/Terry_Hayes_\(politician\) "Terry Hayes \(politician\)") and
businessman Alan Caron have qualified for the ballot as independents. Former
State Senator and former Mayor of [Lewiston](/wiki/Lewiston,_Maine "Lewiston,
Maine") and [Auburn](/wiki/Auburn,_Maine "Auburn, Maine") John Jenkins,
conservative activist Aaron Chadbourne and perennial candidate Kenneth Capron
are running write-in campaigns.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maine_gubernatorial_election,_2018&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

Incumbent Republican [Paul LePage](/wiki/Paul_LePage "Paul LePage") is term-
limited, having been elected twice consecutively in
[2010](/wiki/Maine_gubernatorial_election,_2010 "Maine gubernatorial election,
2010") and [2014](/wiki/Maine_gubernatorial_election,_2014 "Maine
gubernatorial election, 2014"). LePage did not win a majority of the vote
either time (receiving 37.6% in a crowded four-way race in 2010 and 48.2% in a
three-way race in 2014), with Democrats accusing independent candidate [Eliot
Cutler](/wiki/Eliot_Cutler "Eliot Cutler") of splitting the anti-LePage vote
in both instances, though Cutler finished closer to LePage than Democratic
candidate [Libby Mitchell](/wiki/Libby_Mitchell "Libby Mitchell") in the 2010
election.[8]

Maine's history of governors elected without majorities, including LePage, was
one impetus for the [citizen's referendum](/wiki/Maine_Question_5,_2016 "Maine
Question 5, 2016") to implement [ranked choice voting](/wiki/Ranked-
Choice_Voting "Ranked-Choice Voting").[9][10] Though it was approved by voters
in a [2016 referendum](/wiki/Maine_Question_5,_2016 "Maine Question 5, 2016"),
the [Maine Legislature](/wiki/Maine_Legislature "Maine Legislature") voted to
delay and potentially repeal RCV for all elections after an [advisory
opinion](/wiki/Advisory_opinion "Advisory opinion") by the [Maine Supreme
Judicial Court](/wiki/Maine_Supreme_Judicial_Court "Maine Supreme Judicial
Court") ruled it unconstitutional for general elections for state offices. RCV
supporters succeeded in a people's veto effort to prevent the delay, which
suspends it until a June 2018 referendum vote.[11] RCV supporters were
victorious in the June referendum, and ranked-choice voting will remain in
place for state and federal primaries and federal general elections.[12]

## Republican
primary[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Maine_gubernatorial_election,_2018&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Republican primary")]

Speculation that U.S. Senator [Susan Collins](/wiki/Susan_Collins "Susan
Collins") was considering running for governor arose during the 2015 [Maine
Legislative](/wiki/Maine_Legislature "Maine Legislature") session when
Representative [Matt Moonen](/wiki/Matt_Moonen "Matt Moonen") (D-Portland)
introduced a bill to strip the governor (LePage) of the power to appoint
replacement U.S. Senators in the event of a vacancy and to instead have a
special primary and general election. Moonen denied that he was motivated by
Collins's possible candidacy, saying he was interested only in
counterbalancing Republican-sponsored bills to change how the [Maine Attorney
General](/wiki/Maine_Attorney_General "Maine Attorney General") and [Maine
Secretary of State](/wiki/Maine_Secretary_of_State "Maine Secretary of State")
are chosen. Moonen said Collins had told him speculation about her running for
governor was "silly."[13] Collins, who was the [1994 Republican nominee for
governor](/wiki/Maine_gubernatorial_election,_1994 "Maine gubernatorial
election, 1994"), told [MPBN](/wiki/MPBN "MPBN") News on January 4, 2016 that
though she was "baffled" by the rumors about her being interested in running
for governor, many had encouraged her to run, and she would not rule it
out.[14] In October 2017, Collins said she would not run for governor in
2018.[15]

No Republican candidate has ruled out challenging the results of a ranked-
choice primary in court. [Mary Mayhew](/wiki/Mary_Mayhew "Mary Mayhew") called
for the immediate repeal of RCV, calling it a "scam" and "probably
illegal".[16]

The [Maine Republican Party](/wiki/Maine_Republican_Party "Maine Republican
Party") filed a federal lawsuit in U.S. District Court in
[Bangor](/wiki/Bangor,_Maine "Bangor, Maine") on May 4, 2018, seeking to bar
the use of RCV for its own primary on the grounds that requiring the party to
use it violates its [First
Amendment](/wiki/First_Amendment_to_the_United_States_Constitution "First
Amendment to the United States Constitution") rights to choose its nominee as
it sees fit.[17] U.S. District Court Judge Jon Levy rejected the suit on May
29.[18]

Campaign signs for Democratic candidates for Governor Betsy Sweet, Mark Eves
and Adam Cote at the 2018 Maine Democratic convention at the [Androscoggin
Bank Colisée](/wiki/Androscoggin_Bank_Colis%C3%A9e "Androscoggin Bank
Colisée") in [Lewiston](/wiki/Lewiston,_Maine "Lewiston, Maine").

Almost all Democratic candidates said that they would abide by the results of
the ranked-choice primary, with only [Janet Mills](/wiki/Janet_T._Mills "Janet
T. Mills") refusing to comment on the issue because it was being heard by the
courts.[16]
